Relevant to this discussion: https://mainnet.observer/charts/transactions-per-day/
The last setting was chosen in April 2016, when there was between 200-220k transactions a day. Nowadays there is between 400k and 600k transactions a day.
200k transactions a day is 2.3 tx/s. Why was the value chosen to be thrice as much?
darosior: well you don't want the rate limit to be set to the expected value, because then you'll always have a backlog
so you want some overshoot to account for temporary variations around the average
aside: should we hard cap the inv queue size at some count? theoretically hard to hit but unbounded growth (even with fee payers) seems not great
Ok, i was thinking of it as the default value should roughly match usage, and the temporary increase would kick in for periods of above-average usage.
instagibbs: can it really be hit? Because the number of transaction you send will also grow arbitrarily large with the size of inv_to_send
darosior: in the steady state, the size of the queue will be ~200x the number of transactions you receive between any two sends
for sufficiently large inbound tx rate

Probably impossible in practice due to rate limiting of peers incoming messages or something else I missed? Have a set of 100 peers send tiny high paying fee txns directly, see what happens to inv queues?
instagibbs: yeah would be interesting to have a functional test for this. I suspect it would just lead you to blast INV messages to your peers.
per peer you're limited by the roundtrip time of an INV-GETDATA-TX cycle, times the number of transactions permitted in txrequest
I suppose it would be hard for attacker to get their hands on the txs fast enough, be first to send them to you unilaterally
sipa: sorry could you expand on the ~200x figure? Not sure to follow.
darosior: the formula for how much to send, approximated, is (invs_to_send.size() / 200)
in the steady state, the amount of tx you send equals how many transactions get added to the queue in between two sends
so if you receive say 300 transactions between every two sends, the queue size will tend to grow to a point where invs_to_send.size() / 200 equals 300
which is when invs_to_send.size() == 200 * 300 = 60000

Ok it's the "steady state" definition that i was missing. I wasn't seeing how if you receive on average 2.3 tx per second and send 35 every 5 seconds you end up with a queue of size 200 * 5 * 2.3. Thanks.
darosior: well the steady state is what you end up
the queue will grow until it hits that point

hmmm, i think my conclusion is that we should really set the amount of transaction sent as a function of the time since the last send

because it's a bandwidth consideration... we have some tx send rate that we think would be harmful for (some?) peers, and when we approach that, and can't send everything anymore, we should prefer higher-feerate things
but in addition, from a personal DoS protection perspective, we need to limit the size of the queue
what about: send_now = std::min(to_send.size(), time_since_last_send * R + (to_send.size() ** 2) / M)
where R is the "everyone can handle this tx rate" number, and M is the maximum queue size
R could be different for outbound and inbound; if not, the number of txn per inv will be lower for outbounds than for inbounds, as they have more frequent sends - but maybe that's ok

i think the main benefit of the queue is that it allows the network to prioritise relaying the high-pri/high-fee txs at a rate similar to what can be confirmed, relegating low fee backlog txs to only being relayed when there's a lull. my take is that in that context, just dropping the low fee txs and not relaying them at all would be better, provided there's some way for them to get picked back up
when the mempool empties out (which could just be "the sending wallet resubmits")

#topic Support for Ubuntu 22.04 LTS as a build platform (hebasto)
Ubuntu 22.04 reaches end of standard support in April 2027. See: https://ubuntu.com/about/release-cycle
By the time Bitcoin Core v31.0 is released, Ubuntu 26.04 LTS will be available.
Ubuntu 22.04s default repositories provide dependency packages that are outdated and problematic to maintain, such as: CMake 3.22.1, Qt 6.2.4, Cap'n Proto 0.8.0
Furthermore, Ubuntu 22.04s default repositories do not provide the minimum required Clang version.
My initial proposed action was to stop considering Ubuntu 22.04 as a build platform starting from the v31 release cycle.

However, during conversation on IRC on 2025-09-09, sipa argued that we may end "in a situation where some important user chooses not to upgrade because they want to build from source, and they're stuck on an older platform"
And fanquake pointed on such real world case where "a lot of Armory users are stuck on v27 branch".

my impression is more that for individual upgrades/dependency requirements, we have an ad-hoc discussion for benefits vs. which use/build platforms those would drop

The question for my fellow collegues is can we ask users who will build Bitcoin Core v31+ from source on Ubuntu 22.04 to install newer CMake from https://cmake.org/download/ or from some other package manager?
If so, we can bump the minimum supported CMake version in the v31 release cycle up to 3.25, same as in Debian Bookworm (oldstable).

Tangentially, i've had report of people stuck on  27 because of our glibc bump. fanquake also had some. I would suspect there is more. ah, ok so the reason the current formula is so bad is that the inbound transaction rate (n) required to sustain a queue size of 1000
is n - R = 5
with sipa's formula it's n - R = M
(n = R + 5M/M and n = R + M^2/M)
and the time to clear (when n = 0)for a queue k if no new tx'es arrive is sqrt(M / R) * arctan ( k / sqrt(M * R) ) in sipa's suggested formula and (M / 5) * ln|1 + 5k/MR| in the current formula

with M=1000 and R=7: 11.95 * arctan(k/83.6) in the quadratic formula and 200 * ln|1 + k/1400| in the linear formula, with arctan(inf) = pi/2, the quadratic formula is bounded to never take longer than ~18.77 seconds to clear the queue if there are no inbound transactions
